Question_1.Context: Electrospinning is a technique used to create fibers of different sizes and morphologies from a polymer solution.
Question_1.Question: What is the typical outcome of electrospinning a polymer solution?
Question_1.C: Creation of a monolithic polymer block
Question_1.Source: Electrospinning is a relatively simple technique for producing continuous fibers of various sizes and morphologies.

Question_2.Context: Poly(3-hydroxybutarate-co-3-hydroxyvalerate), or PHBV, is a biopolymer that can be electrospun into fibers.
Question_2.Question: What is an intrinsic property of PHBV when electrospun into fibers?
Question_2.Source: In this study, an intrinsically hydrophilic poly(3-hydroxybutarate-co-3-hydroxyvalerate) (PHBV) biopolymer strain was electrospun from a solution under optimal processing conditions to produce bilayers of beadless micro-fibers and beaded nano-fibers.

Question_3.Context: The incorporation of silica nanoparticles into a polymer matrix can alter the surface properties of the resulting fibers.
Question_3.Question: What effect does the incorporation of silica nanoparticles have on the surface of electrospun PHBV fibers?
Question_3.D: Reduces the porosity of the fibers
Question_3.Source: Incorporation of polydimethylsiloxane (PDMS) treated silica into the electrospinning solutions resulted in a non-wetting state with increased fiber roughness and enhanced porosity.

Question_4.Context: Stearic acid can be used to modify the surface of fibers to alter their interaction with water.
Question_4.Question: What is the effect of treating PHBV/SiO2 fibrous mats with stearic acid at an elevated temperature?
Question_4.A: Decreases the hydrophilicity of the fibers
Question_4.B: Increases the hydrophilicity of the fibers
Question_4.C: Has no effect on the fibers' properties
Question_4.D: Makes the fibers dissolve in water
Question_4.Source: The SiO2–incorporated fibrous mats were then treated with stearic acid at an activation temperature of 80 °C. This treatment caused fiber surface plasticization, creating a tertiary hierarchical roughness owing to the interaction of PHBV chains with the polar carboxyl groups of the stearic acid.

Question_5.Context: Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) is a technique used to analyze the surface morphology of materials.
Question_5.Question: What information can be obtained about electrospun fibers using scanning electron microscopy (SEM)?
Question_5.A: The electrical conductivity of the fibers
Question_5.B: The influence of process parameters on surface morphology
Question_5.C: The thermal stability of the fibers
Question_5.D: The molecular weight of the polymer
Question_5.Source: Scanning electron microscopy was used to assess the influence of the electrospinning process parameters and the incorporation of nanoparticles on surface morphology of the fibers.

Question_6.Context: Energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) is an analytical technique used in conjunction with SEM.
Question_6.Question: What does energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) confirm in the context of electrospun fibers?
Question_6.A: The molecular structure of the polymer
Question_6.B: The presence of specific elemental species
Question_6.C: The crystallinity of the polymer fibers
Question_6.D: The exact chemical formula of the polymer
Question_6.Source: Energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy confirmed the presence of SiO2 nanoparticles.

Question_7.Context: Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) is a technique used to identify chemical bonds in a material by producing an infrared absorption spectrum.
Question_7.Question: What can Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) reveal about electrospun fibers?
Question_7.B: The tensile strength of the fibers
Question_7.C: The incorporation of nanoparticles and their interaction with the polymer
Question_7.Source: Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy was performed to study the incorporation of SiO2 and the interaction of stearic acid with PHBV at various concentrations.

Question_8.Context: Differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) is a thermoanalytical technique that measures the heat flow associated with material transitions as a function of temperature.
Question_8.Question: What does differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) measure in the context of PHBV fibers?
Question_8.A: The color change temperature of the fibers
Question_8.B: The electrical resistance change temperature of the fibers
Question_8.C: The melting temperature and enthalpy of the fibers
Question_8.D: The solubility temperature of the fibers in water
Question_8.Source: The effect of surface modifications on thermal properties was evaluated using differential scanning calorimetry (DSC), specifically, the phase change thermodynamics of the PHBV/SiO2 composite upon modification with SA.

Question_9.Context: The degree of crystallinity in polymers can be influenced by the addition of fillers and plasticizers.
Question_9.Question: How does the incorporation of nanoparticles and plasticization affect the thermal properties of PHBV?
Question_9.B: Does not affect the crystalline fraction
Question_9.D: Only changes the color of the polymer
Question_9.Source: The incorporation of nanoparticles and plasticization altered the thermal properties of PHBV and a decrease in crystalline fraction was observed.

Question_10.Context: Contact angle measurements can indicate the wetting behavior of a surface, with certain angles suggesting hydrophobic or superhydrophobic properties.
Question_10.Question: What static water contact angle (WCA) and roll-off angle are indicative of superhydrophobic surfaces?
Question_10.Source: As a rule, surfaces having a WCA ≥ 150° and roll-off angles ≤ 10° are considered to be superhydrophobic surfaces.
